list.title: Question 1
list.content: Consider the function $f(x)=\dfrac{3x+4}{2x+k}$. - Write down the domain of $f$ in terms of $k$. [1] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$ in terms of $k$. [2] - Hence write down the value of $k$ such that $f(x)$ is a self-inverse function.[1]

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Consider the function $\displaystyle f(x)=b+\frac{4}{x+a}$, $\hspace{1em}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$. The equation of the vertical asymptote of $f(x)$ is $x=2$ and $f(\tfrac{2}{3})=0$. - Write down the value of $a$.[1] - Hence, find the value of $b$. [3] - Hence, write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote.[1]

list.title: Question 3
list.content: A rational function is defined by $f(x) = a + \dfrac{b}{x-c}$, for $x \neq c$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$. The following diagram represents the graph of $y = f(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e4669a2-bbd0-4789-8b97-237e21ae7852/images/57e3eb0c-9ca8-404f-a8a8-d44ee564af63/174d0bc6234e556e44492ded9dca1f7d93a7be93.svg) Using the information on the graph, - state the value of $a$ and the value of $c$ ; [2] - find the value of $b$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{a = -4}$  and
$\answer{c = 4}$
- The point P lies on the graph of $y = f(x)$.
Hence, using the coordinates of P, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.5em} 0 &= f(6) \\[6pt]
  0 &= -4 + \dfrac{b}{6-4} \\[2pt]
  4 &= \dfrac{b}{2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b = 8} \hspace{1.9em}
  $$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The function $f$ is of the form $f(x) = \dfrac{ax+b}{2x+c}$, for
$x \neq -\dfrac{c}{2}$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$.
Given
that the graph of $y = f(x)$ has asymptotes $x = -5$ and $y = 2$, and
that the point
P$\left(1,-\dfrac{1}{12}\right)$ lies on the graph, find the values of
$a, b$ and $c$.
list.markScheme:
Using the vertical asymptote $x = -5$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{[denominator of $f$ at $-5$]} &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
2(-5) + c &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5em} \answer{c = 10}
$$

Using the horizontal asymptote $y = 2$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.1em} \lim_{x\rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 2 \\[6pt]
\dfrac{a}{2} &= 2 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{4.4em} \answer{a = 4}
$$

Using the coordinates of the point P, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(1) &= -\dfrac{1}{12} \\[6pt]
\hspace{3.4em} \dfrac{4+b}{2+10} &= -\dfrac{1}{12} \\[10pt]
4+b &= -1 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5.2em} \answer{b = -5}
$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{2}{x-a} + b$, for $x \neq a$. The line $x = 1$ is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Write down the value of $a$. [1] The graph of $y = f(x)$ passes through the point P$(0,3)$. - Find the value of $b$. [3] - Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{a=1}$
- Using the coordinates of P, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(0) &= 3 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{2}{0-1} + b &= 3 \\[6pt]
  -2+b &= 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b = 5} \hspace{0.3em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty}\left[\dfrac{2}{x-1} + 5\right] \\[6pt]
  &= 0 + 5 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{3x-6}{x+1}$, for $x\neq-1$. - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the equation of: - the horizontal asymptote; - the vertical asymptote. [3] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{3x-6}{x+1} &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    3x-6 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    x &= 2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept
are  $\answer{(2,0)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.8em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{3(0)-6}{0+1} \\[6pt]
    &= -6\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept
are  $\answer{(0,-6)}$

- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \lim_{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(x) &= \dfrac{3}{1} \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    &= 3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the horizontal
asymptote is
$\answer{y = 3}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/afc5956d-9845-488e-810c-bb260e443e8e/images/da49f8cb-1329-4f71-ab39-25e1b4760c7c/5aa8339f9ee09bb9f920e735960c8b3bddfc8e2c.svg)

list.title: Question 7
list.content: The function $f$ is given by $f(x) = \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16}$, for $x \neq \pm 4$. - Prove that $f$ is an even function. [2] - - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Write down the range of $f$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq \pm 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{4(-x)^2 - 128}{(-x)^2 - 16} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16} \\[12pt]
  &= f(x)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $f$ is an even function.
- 
  - If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4b2579c-edb3-474f-9012-eba8d8995131/images/99bd6e4e-6a5d-4072-8d6f-a53d9d744a19/6c198522156a50253fdb14e877863a1523046369.svg)


  - $\answer{(-\infty,4) \cup [8,\infty)}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5}$, for $x\neq\dfrac{5}{2}$. - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the equation of: - the horizontal asymptote; - the vertical asymptote. [3] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] The graphs of $f(x)$ and $f^{-1}(x)$ have two points of intersection. - Find the coordinates of the two points of intersection. Give your answers to two decimal places. [3] - Hence find the equation of the perpendicular bisector to the two points of intersection. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5} &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    3x+4 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    x &= -\dfrac{4}{3}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are $\answer{\left(-\dfrac{4}{3},0\right)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{3(0)+4}{2(0)-5} \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{4}{5}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept are $\answer{\left(0,-\dfrac{4}{5}\right)}$

- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \lim_{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(x) &= \dfrac{3}{2} \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the horizontal asymptote is $\answer{y = \dfrac{3}{2}}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    [\text{denominator of $f$}] &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    2x-5 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= \dfrac{5}{2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical asymptote is $\answer{x = \dfrac{5}{2}}$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/61d6ea19-c9b6-4e43-b863-25670815218d/aa1013a.PNG)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y &= \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5} \hspace{5.5em} \left[\text{where } y = f(x)\right]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= \dfrac{3y+4}{2y-5} \hspace{3em} \left[\text{where } y = f^{-1}(x)\right] \\[8pt]
  x(2y-5) &= 3y+4 \\[8pt]
  2xy - 5x &= 3y +4 \\[8pt]
  2xy - 3y &= 5x + 4 \\[8pt]
  y(2x - 3) &= 5x + 4 \\[8pt]
  y &= \dfrac{5x+4}{2x-3} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-3em}\tcbhighmath{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{5x+4}{2x-3}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Sketching $f(x)$ and $f^{-1}(x)$ on the same axes, we can find the points of intersection using the G.D.C.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/897ceffb-d901-4e38-a2bb-f444d24cc122/aa1013b.PNG)


- The midpoint of AB is given by

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2} , \dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}\right) &= \left(\dfrac{-0.45+4.45}{2} , \dfrac{-0.45+4.45}{2}\right) \\[8pt]
  &= (2,2)
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Point A and point B both lie on the line $y=x$, which has gradient $m=1$. Therefore the perpendicular bisector has gradient $m=-1$.
  The equation of the perpendicular bisector is given by

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[8pt]
  y - 2 &= -(x - 2) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.525em}\tcbhighmath{y = -x + 4}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{4-ax}{5x - 2}$. - Write down the equation of the vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.[1] The line $y = -1.4$ is a horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Find the value of $a$.[2] - The line $y = x - c$, where $c \in \mathbb{R}^+$, intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at exactly one point. Find the possible values of $c$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $5x-2=0$, we have $\tcbhighmath{x = \dfrac{2}{5}}$
- The horizontal asymptote will be equal to $\displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}f(x)$. We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}f(x) &= \displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}\dfrac{4-ax}{5x-2} \\[8pt]
  -1.4 &= -\dfrac{a}{5} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{a=7}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = |f(x)|$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/423ecaf7-2110-4ebe-8d00-cb3ef860ab02/aa1027a.PNG)


  A line of the form $y = x - c$ where $c \in \mathbb{R}^+$ has a gradient of $m=1$ and a $y$-intercept that is less than zero. The following diagram shows the graph of $y=x$, which represents an absolute upper limit for the $y$-intercept.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/66fa47d7-6be3-4bd7-bfc8-104af16f2d66/aa1027b.PNG)


  The line $y=x$ intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at three points.
  The following diagram shows the graph of $y=x-0.571$, which passes through the point A$(0.571,0)$ and has a $y$-intercept of $-0.571$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/47bdebc2-8242-44ff-8e71-2793f3857f00/aa1027c.PNG)


  The line $y=x-0.571$ intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at two points. Any line of gradient $m=1$ and $y$-intercept of less than $-0.571$ will intersect the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ exactly once.
  Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{c > 0.571}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$, for $x \neq -1$. - For the graph of $f$, find: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept; - the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5] Let $g(x) = x-3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$ intersect at points A and B. - Find the coordinates of A and B. [5] - Find the equation of the straight line that passes through A and B, giving your answer in the form $y = mx + c$. [3] - Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular to the line passing through A and B. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Since the equation $f(x) = 0$ has no solutions, there are
$\answer{\text{no \(x\)-intercepts}}$
  - Evaluating $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(0) &= \dfrac{5}{0+1} \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]
    &= 5\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,5)}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Solving the equation $f(x) = g(x)$ for $x$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \dfrac{5}{x+1} &= x-3 \\[6pt]
  5 &= (x+1)(x-3) \\[9pt]
  5 &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[9pt]
  0 &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[10pt]
  0 &= (x+2)(x-4) \\[10pt]
  x &= -2,\hspace{0.25em}4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $g(x) = x-3$
for $x = -2$ and $x = 4$, we find

  $$
  \hspace{3.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  y &=& g(-2) &=& -5 \\[9pt]
  y &=& g(4) &=& 1
  \end{array}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(-2,-5)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(4,1)}$
- Using the gradient formula with A$(-2,-5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{AB}} &= \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1-(-5)}{4-(-2)} \\[10pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(-2,-5)$ and $m = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.15em} y - (-5) &= (1)(x-(-2)) \\[6pt]
  y + 5 &= x + 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = x-3} \hspace{0.15em}
  $$

- $\answer{m_{\perp\mathrm{AB}} = -1}$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{9-12x}{cx - 20}$, for $x \neq \dfrac{20}{c}$, where $c \neq 0$. - The line $x = 5$ is a vertical asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Find the value of $c$. - Write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$.[4] - The line $y = h$, where $h \in \mathbb{R}$, intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at exactly one point. Find the possible values of $h$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the equation of the vertical asymptote, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{8.6em} \\[6pt]
    5c - 20 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    5c &= 20 \\[4pt]
    &\hspace{-0.67em} \answer{c = 4}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - $\answer{y = -3}$

- If we draw the graph of $y = |f(x)|$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3658e86-b348-445b-bade-3ea93bdc0f36/images/7c07f0a2-c2b1-440d-be6c-385ece839f36/05e9ba9d7a31d35d6e66b11e5f0ab06197d7db87.svg)


  A line of the form $y = h$ can intersect the graph of $y = |f(x)|$
exactly at one point either at A or at B, as shown on the diagram
above.
  Hence we find
$\answer{h = 0,\hspace{0.25em}3}$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: - Sketch the curve $y = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same axes, clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes. [3] - Find the exact solutions to the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- Let $f(x) = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ where $x \in \mathbb{R}$,
$x \neq 2$.
  Since $f(x) < 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq 2$, the curve
$y = f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} y &= f(0) \\[12pt]
  &= -\left|-\dfrac{5}{2}\right| \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{5}{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point A$(0,-5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) = 0 \hspace{3.9em}
  $$

  Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = 2$. Hence the line $x = 2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y = -4-x$ are B$(-4,0)$ and
C$(0,-4)$.
  If we sketch the curve $y = f(x)$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same
axes, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)


- If we solve the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x < 2$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= -\dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 < 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{7.7em} (x+4)(x-2) &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[13pt]
  (x + 3)(x - 1) &= 0 \\[13pt]
  x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we simplify the equation
$x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x > 2$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= \dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 > 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{10em} (x+4)(x-2) &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 13 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12em} x &= \dfrac{-2+\sqrt{2^2-4(1)(-13)}}{2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x > 2$}] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{-2+2\sqrt{14}}{2} \\[12pt]
  &= -1 + \sqrt{14} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $\text{\(x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}\)}$ are  $\answer{-3,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}\textstyle -1 + \sqrt{14}}$

list.title: Question 13
list.content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = 1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3}$, for $x \neq -3$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes and points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [4] - Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Solve the inequality $|f(x)| < 2$. [4] - Solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= 0 \\[11pt]
  5x + 3 &= 0 \\[10pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{3}{5} \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
P$(-3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 1 + \dfrac{4}{1} \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the line $y = 5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = -3$. Hence the line
$x = -3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch of the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)


- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3.7em}  \\[8pt]
  f\left(y\right) &= x\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} 1+ \dfrac{4y}{y+3} &= x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5y+3}{y+3} &= x \\[10pt]
  5y+3 &= xy+3x \\[16pt]
  (5-x)y &= 3x-3 \\[10pt]
  y &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for
$f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x}}$
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\[9pt]
  1 + \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[10pt]
  (5x+3)(5-x) &= (3x-3)(x+3) \\[12pt]
  \hspace{1.6em} 25x - 5x^2 + 15 -3x &= 3x^2 + 9x -3x - 9 \\[12pt]
  -8x^2 + 16x + 24 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.6em} \answer{x = -1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  && |f(x)| &<& 2 \\[13pt]
  -2 &<& f(x) &<& 2 \\[12pt]
  f^{-1}(-2) &<& x &<& f^{-1}(2) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$}]
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x = -2$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} f^{-1}(-2) &= \dfrac{3(-2)-3}{5-(-2)} \\[3pt]
  &= -\dfrac{9}{7} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for
$x = 2$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} f^{-1}(2) &= \dfrac{3(2)-3}{5-2}  \hspace{0.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$|f(x)| < 2$ is
$\answer{-\frac{9}{7}<x<1}$
- If we solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ for $|x|$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} 1+ \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 2 \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 1 \\[10pt]
  4|x| &< |x|+3 \\[16pt]
  3|x| &< 3 \\[16pt]
  |x| &< 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ is
$\answer{-1<x<1}$

list.title: Question 14
list.content: The function $f$ is defined as $f(x)=\dfrac{x^2-(a+3)x+3a}{x-2}$, where $x\in \mathbb{R}, x\neq 2$. The parameter $a$ can be any real number. - For this part of the question $a=4$. - Find the equations of the vertical and oblique asymptotes of $f(x)$. - Justify that $f$ has two stationary points. Note: you do not need to find the coordinates of these points. - Hence, sketch $f(x)$ and identify the asymptotes and axis intercepts.[9] - Show that $f(x)$ will always have at least one root for any value of $a$. [3] - Find the range of values of $a$ for which $f$ has no stationary points. [4] - Show that the root of the equation of the oblique asymptote is always exactly 1 unit away from one of the roots of $f(x)$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The vertical asymptote occurs when the denominator is equal to zero

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        x-2&=0\\
        x&=2 
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore the equation of the vertical asymptote is $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{x=2}$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    To find the oblique asymptote we use algebraic long division

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{M1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/be5cd178-0dee-44aa-b522-868d3d4ac407/images/19c6b701-8702-4bc6-acd7-6845beb54d0c/a1040-1.png)


    Using this result we can rewrite $f(x)$

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        f(x)&=x-5+\frac{2}{x-2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We can see that as $x$ tends to positive or negative infinity $f(x)$ tends to $x-5$.
    Therefore the equation of the oblique asypmpote is $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{y=x-5}$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  - To find stationary points we need to solve the equation $f'(x)=0$. Using the quotient rule we find

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        f'(x)&=\frac{(2x-7)(x-2)-(1)(x^2-7x+12)}{(x-2)^2} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
        &=\frac{2x^2-7x-4x+14-x^2+7x-12)}{(x-2)^2)}\\
        &=\frac{x^2-4x+2}{(x-2)^2} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
    \end{align*}
    $$

    By solving $f'(x)=0$ we form a quadratic equation

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        x^2-4x+2&=0
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The discriminant of the equation is

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        (-4)^2-4(1)(2)&=8\\
        &>0 \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The discriminant is greater than zero,
    therefore$\answer{f(x) \text{ has two stationary points}}$.
  - To find the $y-$intercepts we evaluate $f(0)=\tfrac{12}{-2}$, therefore the $y-$axis intercept occurs at $(0, -6)$
    For the $x-$intercepts we solve $f(x)=0$. Hence $(x-3)(x-4)=0$, the $x-$intercepts occur at $(3, 0)$ and $(4, 0)$.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/be5cd178-0dee-44aa-b522-868d3d4ac407/images/704506d7-2edd-45f7-b7c0-09049d21fab7/AA1040new.png)


    $\answer{\text{Correct asymptotes}}$

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    $\answer{\text{Correct intercepts}}$

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    $\answer{\text{Correct shape}}$

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- We must show that the equation $f(x)=0$ has at least one solution for all values of $a$. For that we can find the discriminant of the numerator

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \triangle&=(-(a+3))^2-4(1)(3a) \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
      &=a^2+6a+9-12a\\
      &=a^2-6a+9\\
      &=(a-3)^2 \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  As $(a-3)^2\geq 0$ for all values of $a$ then

  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  $\answer{f(x) \text{ will always have at least one root.}}$
- Find the derivative of $f(x)$ using the quotient rule

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      f'(x)&=\frac{(2x-(a+3))(x-2)-(1)(x^2-(a+3)x+3a)}{(x-2)^2}\\
      &=\frac{2x^2-4x\cancel{-ax}+2a\cancel{-3x}+6-x^2\cancel{+ax}\cancel{+3x}-3a}{(x-2)^2}\\
      &=\frac{x^2-4x-a+6}{(x-2)^2}\tag*{\textbf{(A1)}}\\
  \end{align*}
  $$

  We must find the range of values of $a$ for which there are no solutions to the equation $f'(x)= 0$. We can find the discriminant of the numerator found above

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \triangle&=(-4)^2-4(1)(6-a) \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\
      &=4a-8
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore there are no solutions to $f'(x)= 0$ when $4a-8<0$, so we have no stationary points for $a<2$.

  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  Also, when $a=2$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      f'(x) &= \frac{x^2-4x+4}{(x-2)^2}\\
      &= \frac{(x-2)^2}{(x-2)^2}\\
      &= 1
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence when $a=2$, we have a constant gradient of $1$, and $f(x)$ is a linear function (with a hole at $x=2$) and hence has no stationary point.
  Hence $f$ has no stationary points for $\answer{a \leq 2}.$

  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
- We can find the equation of the oblique asymptote in terms of $a$ using algebraic long division
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/be5cd178-0dee-44aa-b522-868d3d4ac407/images/c944ad47-d65d-4477-9dcb-7731cf4bceca/a1040-3.png)



  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{M1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  As $x$ tends to a large number we can see that the equation of the oblique asymptote is $y=x-a-1$.
  The root of the oblique asymptote occurs when $y=0$, therefore the root is $x=a+1$.

  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  Now lets consider the roots of $f(x)$, you may notice that you can factorise $f(x)$

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      f(x)&=(x-a)(x-3)
  \end{align*}
  $$

  However, if you did not realise this you could use the quadratic formula (or complete the square) to find the roots of $f$.
  Hence, $f$ has the two roots $x_1=a$ and $x_2=3$.

  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  Therefore the root of the oblique aysmptote, $x=a+1$
  $\answer{\text{ is always one more than } x_1}$.

  $$
   \tag*{\textbf{R1}}
  $$

  $\textcolor{white}{gap}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Consider the function defined by $f(x) = \dfrac{7}{x^2+6x-7}$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x\neq -7$, $x\neq 1$. - Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, showing the values of any axes intercepts, the coordinates of any local maxima and minima, and the graphs of any asymptotes. [6] Next, consider the function $g$ defined by $g(x)=\dfrac{7}{x^2+6x-7}$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x> 1$. - Show that $g^{-1}(x)=-3 + \sqrt{\dfrac{16x+7}{x}}$. [6] - State the domain of $g^{-1}$. [1] Now, consider the function $h$ defined by $h(x)=\arccos\left(\dfrac{x}{7}\right)$. - Given that $\left(h\circ g\right)(a) = \dfrac{\pi}{3}$, find the value of $a$. Give your answer in the form $p+q\sqrt{2}$ where $p$, $q\in \mathbb{Z}$. [7]
list.markScheme:
- First we note that the function is undefined for $x=-7$ and $x=1$. Therefore there are two vertical asymptotes, $x=-7$ and $x=1$.
  To determine the horizontal asymptote, we examine the behaviour of the function as $x \to \pm \infty$.
  $\displaystyle{\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}}f(x)=0$
  Therefore the horizontal asymptote is $y=0$.
  By calculating $f(0)$, we find that the $y$-intercept is $(0,-1)$.
  Next, we find the $x$-intercepts by solving the equation $f(x)=0$:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f(x) &= 0 \\[10pt]
  \dfrac{7}{x^2+6x-7} &= 0 \\[10pt]
  7 &\neq 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  There are no $x$-intercepts.
  Now we need to determine any maxima or minima. To do this, we note that the reciprocal function is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \dfrac{1}{f(x)} &= \dfrac{x^2+6x-7}{7} \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{7}(x+7)(x-1)
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The graph of the reciprocal function is a parabola:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae4ca068-360f-454a-aa85-45ade395c2f5/images/feee365c-c170-4040-9b1c-94787db2210a/AA927a.PNG)


  The reciprocal function has a minimum at $\left(-3,-\dfrac{16}{7}\right)$ and therefore $f(x)$ has a maximum at $\left(-3,-\dfrac{7}{16}\right)$.
  Finally, we need to determine the behaviour of the function around the vertical asymptotes. Again, we can use the reciprocal function to determine this.
  $\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\bullet$ As $x \to -7^-$, $\dfrac{1}{f(x)} \to 0^+$. Therefore $f(x) \to +\infty$.$\\[10pt]$
$\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\bullet$ As $x \to -7^+$, $\dfrac{1}{f(x)} \to 0^-$. Therefore $f(x) \to -\infty$.$\\[10pt]$
$\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\bullet$ As $x \to 1^-$, $\dfrac{1}{f(x)} \to 0^-$. Therefore $f(x) \to -\infty$. $\\[10pt]$
$\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\bullet$ As $x \to 1^+$, $\dfrac{1}{f(x)} \to 0^+$. Therefore $f(x) \to +\infty$.$\\[10pt]$
  Therefore the graph of $y=f(x)$ is as follows:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae4ca068-360f-454a-aa85-45ade395c2f5/images/811951dd-4da1-48ee-bbc1-0cbfc69afa2e/AA927b.PNG)


- By switching $x$ and $g(x)$, we create the inverse function:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= \dfrac{7}{y^2+6y-7} \hspace{3em}[\text{where }y=g^{-1}(x)]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Given that the domain of $g$ is $x>1$, the range of $g^{-1}$ is $g^{-1}(x)>1$. Therefore $y>1$.
  Rearranging to make $y$ the subject, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y^2+6y-7 &= \dfrac{7}{x} \\[8pt]
  y^2 + 6y  &= 7+\dfrac{7}{x} \\[8pt]
  (y + 3)^2 - 9 &= 7+\dfrac{7}{x} \hspace{3em}[\text{By completing the square}]\\[8pt]
  (y + 3)^2 &= 16 + \dfrac{7}{x} \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{16x + 7}{x} \\[8pt]
  y + 3 &= \sqrt{\dfrac{16x + 7}{x}} \hspace{3em}[\text{Since $y>1$}]\\[8pt]
  y &= -3 + \sqrt{\dfrac{16x + 7}{x}} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-3em}\tcbhighmath{g^{-1}(x) = -3 + \sqrt{\dfrac{16x+7}{x}}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- We could note that $g(x)=f(x)$ for $x>1$, and therefore using our graph from part (a), the range is $g(x)>0$. Therefore the domain of $g^{-1}(x)$ is $\answer{x>0}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  g(a)&=\dfrac{7}{a^2+6a-7}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(h\circ g\right)(a) &= \arccos\left(\dfrac{g(a)}{7}\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \arccos\left(\dfrac{1}{a^2+6a-7}\right)
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \arccos\left(\dfrac{1}{a^2+6a-7}\right) &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} \\[8pt]
  \cos\left(\arccos\left(\dfrac{1}{a^2+6a-7}\right)\right) &= \cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{1}{a^2+6a-7} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \hspace{3em}\bigg[\text{since }\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)=\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg]\\[8pt]
  a^2+6a-7 &= 2\\[8pt]
  a^2+6a &= 9 \\[8pt]
  (a+3)^2-9 &= 9 \hspace{3em}[\text{By completing the square}]\\[8pt]
  (a+3)^2 &= 18 \\[8pt]
  a+3 &= \pm\sqrt{18} \\[8pt]
  a+3 &= \pm 3\sqrt{2} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.55em}\tcbhighmath{ a = -3 + 3\sqrt{2}} \hspace{3em} [\hspace{0.05em}\text{since }a>1\hspace{0.05em}]
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Consider the function defined by $f(x) = (2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x>p$. - Find the value of $p$. [2] - Find an expression for $f'(x)$. [3] The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of inflexion. - Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or concave up over its domain. [3] The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x$, for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x>-3$. - Find an expression for $g'(x)$. [4] - Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of $g'(x)$.[2] - Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3] - Solve $f(x)-3$.[5]
list.markScheme:
- Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$\answer{ p=-3}$
- Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x\big] \\[10pt]
  & \answer{=\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Differentiating $f'$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{(x+3)(2)-(2x-6)}{\left(x+3\right)^2} + \dfrac{2}{x+3} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{2x+18}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, over $x>-3$, we have $f''(x)>0$. Therefore,
$\answer{f \text{ is concave up}}$
- Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x\right] \\[12pt]
  &=3(x+3)\left(-\dfrac{1}{(x+3)^2}\right)+1  \\[8pt]
  & =\dfrac{-3}{x+3}+1 \\[10pt] 
  & \answer{=\dfrac{x}{x+3}} \end{aligned}
  $$

- The denominator of $g'$ is zero when $x=-3$.
Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(x=-3\) is a vertical asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $\infty$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\to \infty} g'(x) &= \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{x}{x+3}%\cdot \dfrac{\dfrac{1}{x}}{\dfrac{1}{x}}
  \\[8pt]
  & = \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{1}{1+\dfrac{3}{x}\rule[-2mm]{0pt}{7.2mm}} \\[6pt]
  & = 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(y=1\) is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
- From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{x}{x+3}\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{3}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, $g''(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(0) &= 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)+0 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -3\ln(3)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using logarithm properties, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &< g(x) \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) + x &< 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right) + x \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) &< -3\ln(x+3) \\[15pt]
  (2x-3)\ln(x+3) &< 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Thus, we have two options

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[2x-3<0\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)>0\right] &\text{  or  } \left[2x-3>0 \enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  \left[x<1.5\enskip\&\enskip\ln(x+3)>0\right]&\text{ or } \left[x>1.5\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  x < 1.5\enskip & \&\enskip 1<x+3 \hspace{2em}[\text{since }\ln(x+3)>0\text{ for }x>1.5]\\[8pt]
  -2 <& \hspace{0.1em}x < 1.5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $\answer{-2 <  x < 1.5}$
